section.p: The Workflow Definition file is used with the Airflow GUI. This file defines environment, tasks and workflows.

Environment defines the Maestro environment for performing instantiation and upgrade tasks without logging to the VM. To perform the installation and upgrade tasks, the clouds-config.yaml and keystone_info files must be stored on the Maestro VM. This can be done by including the files into the package or adding the contents of the files to Environment. If the goal is to run automation test tasks only, then Environment configuration is not needed and can be completely removed. However, by configuring Environment, as shown in the sample Workflow Definition file, you ensure that the clouds-config.yaml and keystone_info files are created in the path provided for the parameter <file_path> and with the content provided for the parameter <content>. Although <clouds-config> and <keystone> parameters are not mandatory, these parameters are the only two supported parameters for Environment.

note.p: <$PACKAGE_ABS_PATH> is an environment variable that can be used to fetch the absolute path to the package. For example, when saving sample_package, the pathname of the clouds-config.yaml file will be /opt/sps/packages/sample_package/configs/clouds-config.yaml.

section.p: For information on how to configure the clouds-config.yaml file, see .

The following figure shows an example of Environment definition. The content in this figure is representative and should be replaced by the keystone and clouds-config content that works for a particular cloud.

fig.title: Environment definition
fig.codeblock:
Environment: clouds-config: file_path: $PACKAGE_ABS_PATH/configs/clouds-config.yaml content: | # CBAM API info CBAM_IP: 1.1.1.1 CLIENT: spsclient SECRET: 624c4088-3a7a-42d2-bdd0-1d8eeb3ff179
# Full path of the OpenStack keystone file. OS_KEYSTONE_FILE: $PACKAGE_ABS_PATH/configs/keystone_info
# SPS credentials for ISU ROOT_PSWD: "password" TPAADMIN_PSWD: "password" keystone: file_path: $PACKAGE_ABS_PATH/configs/keystone_info content: | export OS_USERNAME="v9999_1" export OS_PASSWORD="password" export OS_AUTH_URL="https://1.1.1.2:13000/v2.0" export OS_PROJECT_NAME="v9999_SPS" export OS_CACERT="$PACKAGE_ABS_PATH/configs/v9999.OS_CACERT.pem"

section.title: CommandConstants
section.p: CommandConstants are the argument values that can be shared between different commands. These argument values apply to the parameter command only. CommandConstants allow users to avoid repeated value declaration and can be used to define constants. CommandConstants can be accessed in command using $ prefix along with the variable name. The following figure shows the declaration of CommandConstants.

fig.title: CommandConstants declaration
fig.codeblock: CommandConstants: local_ip: 1.1.1.1 me_sdc: $PACKAGE_ABS_PATH/configs/me_sdc.json sm_sdc: $PACKAGE_ABS_PATH/configs/sm_sdc.json me_vnf: $PACKAGE_ABS_PATH/configs/me_vnf_conf.json sm_vnf: $PACKAGE_ABS_PATH/configs/sm_vnf_conf.json cloud_conf: $PACKAGE_ABS_PATH/configs/clouds-config.yaml build_path: https://<Images directory URL>/sps-generic-candidates-local/spsmainbuild/<SPS load ID> build_version: <SPS build version>

sectiondiv.p: Each task which is performed with the Airflow GUI has to be defined before it is used in the Deployment Workflow. The task name is in a free form, for example CleanSPSInstall. There is no validation for this and this can be changed appropriately. The following table describes the parameters of a task.

entry.p: This parameter is a shell command which is executed on the Maestro VM.
CommanConstants can be defined for this parameter. For more information, see .
This parameter defines the type of the task.
This parameter is defined as one of the following:
where trigger-remote-workflow and monitor-remote-task are used for the multi-site NCC installation where synchronization between remote Maestro VMs is needed.

row.entry: This parameter defines the threshold level in percentages, which determines whether a task succeeds or fails. This parameter applies to run-test operations.

entry.p: These parameters trigger a workflow on a remote site.

row.entry: This parameter defines the IP address which can be IPv4 or IPv6.
This parameter defines the name of the workflow.
This parameter defines the name of the package.
This parameter is used for sending the task status when the e-mail is configured for the workflow that includes this task.

sectiondiv.p: The workflow is a collection of tasks that are executed in a defined order. A valid workflow must contain at least one task. There can be more than one workflow with a unique name (free form text). Once saved in the Airflow GUI, the Package name will be prefixed to all of the workflow names in the package. This allows to distinguish workflows when there are more than one package in the Maestro VM.

note.p: Parallel workflow execution not supported yet.

sectiondiv.p: The following table describes the parameters of a workflow.

entry.p: This parameter defines the name of the workflow.

row.entry: This parameter defines a list of tasks to execute.

By default this parameter is set to on-demand.

section.title: Reference tasks in Workflow Definition file
section.p: The Workflow Definition file contains the tasks that can be used as a reference or an example. Users can create more tasks as needed. The Workflow Definition file contains the following tasks:

note.p: In the package, RunCustomTestSuite must be stored in customtestsuites directory.

p.b: Tasks defined in Workflow Definition file

sectiondiv.p: The following figure shows the tasks defined in the Workflow Definition file.

fig.title: Tasks in Workflow Definition file
fig.codeblock:
TriggerRemoteSiteWorkflow: operation: trigger-remote-workflow email-subject-prefix: SPS remote-maestro-ip-address: 1.1.1.3 remote-workflow-name: SPSInstallAndTestWorkflow remote-package-name: site_package
MonitorRemoteSiteInstallMETask: operation: monitor-remote-task email-subject-prefix: SPS remote-maestro-ip-address: 1.1.1.3 remote-package-name: site_package remote-workflow-name: SPSInstallAndTestWorkflow remote-task-name: InstallME
MonitorRemoteSiteInstallSMTask: operation: monitor-remote-task email-subject-prefix: SPS remote-maestro-ip-address: 1.1.1.3 remote-package-name: site_package remote-workflow-name: SPSInstallAndTestWorkflow remote-task-name: InstallSM monitor-timeout: 3600
InstallSM: operation: sps-instantiate email-subject-prefix: SPS command: > sudo -i maestro ace sps-instantiate -f $cloud_conf -d $build_path -i $sm_sdc -j $sm_vnf -s sm $build_version
InstallME: operation: sps-instantiate email-subject-prefix: SPS command: > sudo -i maestro ace sps-instantiate -f $cloud_conf -d $build_path -i $me_sdc -j $me_vnf -s me $build_version
# All post install configurations should be written/packaged as a robot suite. RunPostInstallConfiguration: operation: run-test command: > sudo -i maestro spstests run $PACKAGE_ABS_PATH/post-install/PostInstallConfiguration --mesdc $me_sdc --smsdc $sm_sdc --localip $local_ip
# Standard Test suites packaged into Maestro. Use the task names in the # workflow task-list. RunOOBChargingSuite: operation: run-test suite-pass-percentage: 75 command: > sudo -i maestro spstests run OOBChargingSuite --mesdc $me_sdc --smsdc $sm_sdc --localip $local_ip
RunOOBPolicySuite: operation: run-test suite-pass-percentage: 75 command: > sudo -i maestro spstests run OOBPolicySuite --mesdc $me_sdc --smsdc $sm_sdc --localip $local_ip
RunSMFunctionalSuite: operation: run-test command: > sudo -i maestro spstests run SMFunctionalSuite --mesdc $me_sdc --smsdc $sm_sdc --localip $local_ip
RunChargingRegressionSuite: operation: run-test command: > sudo -i maestro spstests run ChargingRegressionSuite --mesdc $me_sdc --smsdc $sm_sdc --localip $local_ip
RunChargingNewFeaturesSuite: operation: run-test command: > sudo -i maestro spstests run ChargingNewFeaturesSuite --mesdc $me_sdc --smsdc $sm_sdc --localip $local_ip
RunPerformanceChargingSuite: operation: run-test command: > sudo -i maestro spstests run PerformanceChargingSuite --mesdc $me_sdc --smsdc $sm_sdc --localip $local_ip
RunPolicyRegressionSuite: operation: run-test command: > sudo -i maestro spstests run PolicyRegressionSuite --mesdc $me_sdc --smsdc $sm_sdc --localip $local_ip
RunPolicyNewFeatureSuite: operation: run-test command: > sudo -i maestro spstests run PolicyNewFeatureSuite --mesdc $me_sdc --smsdc $sm_sdc --localip $local_ip
RunPerformancePolicySuite: operation: run-test command: > sudo -i maestro spstests run PerformancePolicySuite --mesdc $me_sdc --smsdc $sm_sdc --localip $local_ip
RunCustomTestSuite: operation: run-test command: > sudo -i maestro spstests run $PACKAGE_ABS_PATH/customtestsuites/CustomTestSuite --mesdc $me_sdc --smsdc $sm_sdc --localip $local_ip
